div.head: John Ashbrooke Will.
div.p:
In the name of God Amen. The last will and testament of John
Ashbrooke in Charles County being in perfect memory.
I give and bequeath my soule unto the Almighty God and my body to
be entered in the ground and in it to be desently buried as my dear wife
shall see to it.

2d I give and bequeath unto my loving wife one chow call by the name of
Juyne with a chow calf by her side now naming. I give unto my sonne James
one chow called by the name of fortune and two yearlings being heiffers
and come of the above said chow Juyne and all the land that at this
present belongs and dappertains unto me the sd. John onely my wife to enjoy
the sd. land for her life time provided she keeps herself unmaryed but
is that she should mary that the the said James shall tke the said land
into his possession and that my wife shall have nothing to do with it.

3d I give and bequeath unto my Daughter Keese one yoing heafer at two years
of age Called by the name of Gentle.

4 I give and bequeath unto my Daughter Elizabeth one three year olf heaffer
Called by the name of Ham.

5. I give and bequeath unto my Daughter Ann one heaffer called by the name of
Carmakin meat I desire that my sone James if I die shall be a free man and to
disperse of himself as hee shall see fit and likewise to have two gunns which are at
presentmy own but if I die to be at his dispersing meet for the house hold
my desire is that it shall remaine in the house for that good of them all
and no separation to be made as wainscoat I kept and a small loc that my
wife
wife put her in I give unto her.

Sixthly I constitute and appoint my loving wife to be to be Executor and to see
my will performed in all respects whatsoever as is above specified and to the
confination of which I have hereunto set my hand and seal the seventeenth
day of January in the year of our lord. 1677/8.

Signed Sealed & Delivered
In the presents of us
Hrt. Burghitt - Simon Stephens
John Ashbrooke

On the back of the aforegoing will was Endorsed the following probate & petition (to will)
January 24th day 1678. Then Simon Stephens being sworn upon the Evangatent
that he saw and heard John Ashbrooke deceased Sign Seal Deliver &
publish the within mentioned his Last will and testament.
John Stone

Maryland Jst. The Honorable Philip Colvert Esquire Chancellor and Chief Judge
on Comisary Gen. for probate of wlls and granting of administrations for the
province of Maryland the Humble Petition of emprance AshbrookeT & Richard
Clowder who sense the decease of the within named John Ashbrooke
with the said Temprance humbly showeth unto your hon. as.

That your poor and humble petition Temprance Ashbrooke alias Clowder as
also the above mentioned Richard Clowder who hath since s.d John Ashbrooke
death Intermarried with the sd Temperance humbly beegs our hon. that they
may have the liberty to renounce the within mentioned will that the sd
Temprance in the life time of the said John Ashbrooke late of Charles County
deceased proving him a true and faithfull wife unto him the said John in his
life time and all - what follows unintelligable time of there lives together hath
not him by any of the neighbourhood and uputed to have been any ways
- what follows unintelligable Husband and was always willing and ayding
and assisting her dear husband un his life time to worke and and
any lawfull indeavor for the seaveing the small God in his mercy was
pleased to find us during his maternal life yet al the deacease of my
dear
Dear and Loving husnand Ashbrooke he sd John made the within
mentioned deedeas his last will and testament and in the said will
hath not gwen me what in right and according to my life & c
conwensation and obediance I had indeaeour towards him during his
natural life in right he ought to have left me do have matayned &
my pore children lawfully begotten by him of my body but having one
wife before he maryed me by whome he has also children hath made
such provision in his will as the within mencioned that if the
humble petition should chance to marry that which I was forced to do
otherways was not able to maintain myself and change my deceased husband
Ashbrooke lifetime that then I should not have any part or parcell of
the Land to love on during my life but immediately upon that
deliver the Land unto his sonne James Ashbrooke as your hon. may
by the within mentioned will that which if we are forced to
doe we are utterly ruined not having any place to
and worke to mentain our therefore we the said temperance-
Ashbrooke alias Clowder & Richard Clowder her now husband humbly
beegs your hon. of your inward woth Clemency and will
be pleased to grant them liberty of administration in the right of her
thirds or as your hon. thinks fitt both the said temperance & the
said Richard by these presence renouncing teh said will under their
hands the 22nd day of August 1678. And they as in duly bound shall
pray of your hon.
